lg.l: As I strole the City, oft I
see a building large and lofty
Not a bow shot from the Colledge;
Half the Globe from Sence and Knowledge:
By the prudent Architect
plac'd against the Church direct;
makeing good my Grandames Iest;
Near the Church──you know the rest.Tell me what this Pile Contains?
many a head that holds no brains.
these Demoniacks let me Dub
with the names of Legion Club
such Assemblies you might swear
Meet when Butchers bait a Bear;
such a noise and such haranging
when a Brother thief's ahanging.
such a rout & such a Rabble
Run to hear Iack Pudding Babble
such a Crowd that Ordure Throws
on a far less Villians NoseCou'd I from the building's top
hear the rattling thunder drop
while the Devil upon the roof
(If the Devil be thunder proof)
shou'd with Poker with fury red
Crack the Stones and Melt the lead;
drive them down on ev'ry Scull
when the Den of thieves is full;
quite destroy that Harpies Nest
how might then our Isle be blest!
for Divines allow that God
sometimes makes the Devil his rod;
and the Gospel will inform us
He can punish Crimes enormous.
yet should Swift endow the Schools
with his Lunaticks and fools;
with a rood or two of Land;
I Allow the Pile may stand.You perhaps will ask me, why so?
but it is with this Proviso
Since the House is like to last
let a Royal Grant be pass'd
that the Club have right to dwell
Each within his proper Cell;
with a passage left to Creep in
And a hole above for peeping:
Let them, when they once get in,
Sell the Nation for a pin
while they sitt apicking Straws
let them dream of makeing Laws;
while they never hold their tongue,
let them dabble in their Dung;
Let them form a Grand Committee
how to plague & Starve the City;
let them Stare & Storm & frown
when they see a Clergy Gown,
let them ere they Crack a louse,
call for th' orders of the House;
let them with their gosling quills,
Scribble senseless heads of Bills:
we may while they strain their throats,
wipe our Arses with their Votes.
Let Sir Tom, that rampant Ass,
Stuff his Guts with flax & Grass;
But before the Priest he fleeces
Tear the Bible all to peices.
At the Parson Tom──halloo Boy,
worthy Offspring of a Shoe Boy,
footman, traitor, vile seducer,
Perjured Rebell vile Accuser,
lay thy Paultry Priviledge aside
Sprung from Papist & a regicide;
fall aworking like a Mole,
raise the dirt about your holeCome assist me Muse obedient,
let us try some new expedient
shift the Scene for Half an Hour
time & place are in thy power;
thither Gentle Muse Conduct me
I shall Ask & thou instruct me.
see the Muse unbarr the Gate;
hark! the Monkies how they prate!
All the Gods that rule the Soul
Styx thro Hell whose waters roll
let me be Allowed to tell
what I heard in yonder Cell?
Near the Door an entrance gapes,
Crowded round with antick shapes,
Poverty & Grief & Care
Causeless Ioy & true Dispair
Discord Perriwig'd with Snakes
See the dreadfull Stride she takesBy the odious Crew besett
I began to rage & frett
and resolv'd to breake their Pates
'Ere we enter'd at the Gates
had not Clio in the Nick
Whisper'd me let fall thy Stick
What! said I is this the Mad House
These she Answer'd are but Shadows
Phantoms bodyless & vain:
Empty visions of the brain,
In the Porch Briarius stands,
with a bribe in all his hands,
Briarius the Secretary
but we Mortalls call him Carey.
when the rogues their Country fleece
They may hope for pence apeice.Clio who had been so wise
to put on a fools disguise,
to bespeak some approbation
And be thought a near relation;
when she saw two hundred brutes
All involved in wild disputes;
Roaring till their Lungs were spent
Priviledge of Parliament;
Now a new Misfortune feels
dreading to be laid by th' Heels
Never durst a Muse before
Enter that infernal door.
Clio Stifled with the Smell
Into spleen & vapours fell
By the Stygian Steam that flew
from the dire infectious Crew
Not the Stench of Lake Avernus
Cou'd have more offended her Nose
Had she flown but o're the top
she must felt her pinions drop
And by Exhalations dire
(tho a Goddess) must expireIn a fright she Crept away
bravely I resolved to Stay
when I saw the keeper frown
tipping him with Half a Crown
Now, said I, we are alone
Name your Heroes one by oneWho is that Hell featured brawler
Is it Satan? No, 'tis Waller
In what figure can a bard dress
Iack the Grandson of Sir Hardress
Honest keeper drive him further
In his looks are Hell & Murther
see his Scrowling visage drop
Iust as when he Murther'd ThropKeeper shew me where to fix
On the Puppy pair of Dicks?
By their Lanthern Iaws & Leathern
You may know them from their Bretheren
Dick FitzBaker Dick the Player
(Old Acequaintance) are you there
Dear Companions Hug & Kiss
Toast Old Glorious in your Piss
tye them Keeper in a tether
let them stare & stink together:
both are apt to be unruly
Lash them daily lash them duely
tho 'tis hopeless to reclaim 'em
Scorpion rods perhaps may team them
Keeper yon' old dotard Smoke
Sweetly snoreing in his Cloke
who is he? 'tis hum-drum Wynne
Half encompass'd with his Kin────
There observe the tribe of Bingham
for he never fails to bring 'em
And the base Apostate Vesey
with Bishops Scraps grow fat & Grasy
while he sleeps the whole debate
they submissive round him wait;
yet shou'd gladly see the Hunks
In his Grave & Search his trunks.
see they gently pull his Coat
Iust to yawn & give his vote;
Allways true to his vocation
for the Court against the Nation,
Those are Allen's Iack & Bob
first in e'ry wicked Iob,
Son & Brother to a Queer
Brain Sick brute they call a peer,
we must give them better quarter
for their Ancestors trod Morter
And at Howth to boast his fame
On a Chimney carved his NameThere Sit Clements Dilkes & Carter
who each for Hell wou'd die a martyr
Such a triplet cou'd you tell
where to find on this side Hell?
Gallows Carter Dilkes & Clements
Souse them in their own Excrements
Every Mischief's in their hearts
If they fail 'tis want of partsBless us Morgan! art thou there Man?
Bless mine eyes! art thou the Chairman?
Chairman to your overn dam'd Committee!
yet I look on thee with pity
dreadfull sight! what learned Morgan
Metamorphos'd to a Gorgon────!
for thy horrid looks I own
Half Convert me to a Stone──!
hast thou been so long at School,
now to turn a factious fool?────
Alma Mater was thy Mother
Ev'ry young divine thy brother
Thou! a disobedient Varlet
treat thy Mother like a Harlott
thou! ungratefull to thy teachers
who are all grown Reverḍ Preachers
Morgan! wou'd it not Surprize one)
turn thy Nourishment to poison!
when you walk among your books
they reproach you with their looks.
bind them fast or from the Shelves
they'l fall down to right themselves
Homer, Plutarch; Virgil Flaccus
All in Arms prepare to back us
soon repent or put to Slaughter
Ev'ry Greek & Roman Author
will you in the factious Phrase
send the Clergy all to Graze!
and to make your project pass
leave them not one blade of Grass?
How I want thee hum'rous Hogarth,
thou I hear a pleasant rogue art;
were but you overI & I overyou Acequainted
Ev'ry Monster shoud be painted
you shou'd try your graveing tools
on this odious Group of fools;
draw the Beasts while I describe them
form their features while I give them
draw them like for I Assure you
It will need no Carcatura;
draw them so that we may trace
all the Soul in ev'ry face
Keeper I must now retire
you have done what I desire
but I feel my Spirits spent
with the Noise the Sight the ScentPray be patient you shall find
Half the Beasts are still behind
you have hardly seen a Score
I can shew two hundred MoreKeeper I have seen enough
takeing then a pinch of Snuff
I Concluded (looking round them,)
May their own God the Devil Confound them
All (except the fifty two
to whom immortal honours due829-023D
